snippet: The East Coast red knot population has plummeted, partly due to the birds’ dependence on an endangered delicacy: the horseshoe crab eggs they eat on their spring migration along the Atlantic coast.
abstract: Population of the East Coast red knot, a shorebird, has plummeted, partly due to the birds’ dependence on an endangered delicacy: horseshoe crab eggs; scientists warn that without stronger protections for both species, red knots could vanish.
lead_paragraph: The East Coast red knot population has plummeted, partly due to the birds’ dependence on an endangered delicacy: the horseshoe crab eggs they eat on their spring migration along the Atlantic coast.

headline.seo: Red Knots, Horseshoe Crabs and Fight to Survive in Delaware Bay
headline.main: A Bird, a Crab and a Shared Fight to Survive
headline.print_headline: A Bird, a Crab and a Shared Fight to Survive
